class_notes: How do we talk about religion? The oldest distinction is probably true/false (or us/them); we can also speak of religion as positive and negative, liberating and oppressive; sociologically, psychologically, ethically; as text, as performance, as identity, as well as in terms of the traditions (Buddhism, Christianity, etc.) and regions (Asia, America, etc.) and themes (death, sexuality, etc.). But how do you want to speak of religion? This class is designed to explore and expand the possibilities of your own voice(s). We address the history and politics of the concept of "religion," we ask if it is possible to speak of religion "scientifically," we ask how to speak responsibly about religion and violence, and explore issues related to cultural appropriation.
course_description: Critical exploration of philosophical, theological, ethical, and social science theories of religions and methods for the interpretation of religious phenomena.
